OUR TOWNS
Metropolitan Desk; SECTA
As Property Taxes Become a Real Burden, Can Backlash Be Far Off?
By PETER APPLEBOME
901 words
5 October 2009
The New York Times
NYTF
Late Edition - Final
17
English
Copyright 2009 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

The list from census data isn't all that surprising, but there it is.

Westchester County, No. 1. Nassau, No. 2. Hunterdon and Bergen in New Jersey, Nos. 3 and 4, respectively.

And so it goes. Of the 10 counties in the country with the highest median property taxes, every one is in New York or New Jersey.

Or, to look at another table in the Census Bureau's American Community Survey for 2008, of the 10 counties with the highest real estate taxes as a percentage of home value, all 10 are in New York. Or, to try one more, of the states with the highest median real estate taxes overall, New Jersey is No. 1, Connecticut is No. 2 and New York is No. 4 (tax-averse New Hampshire, which does not have a general sales tax or a personal income tax, sneaks in at No. 3).

This, as anyone who breathes oxygen knows, is a high-tax region. But as Richard Nathan packed up his office on Friday after 45 years of studying or participating in state, local and federal tax and budget policies, he wondered if we had finally reached a breaking point.

''I'm a little surprised there hasn't been more heat and more agitation about tax caps and tax burdens in the way there has been in other parts of the country,'' said Dr. Nathan, who retired as co-director of the Nelson A. Rockefeller Institute of Government at the State University of New York at Albany. ''I keep thinking, 'When is this dog going to bark?' And the numbers make you think it's going to be soon. It just feels different right now.''

You can hear some pretty distinct yips in the New Jersey governor's race, where the property tax burden could help the Republicans win their first statewide race this decade (or perhaps not, if the Republican candidate, Christopher J. Christie, looks like he doesn't have answers either). But whether there's anything more than resigned gnashing of teeth by suburban swing voters in all three states will say a lot about the future of local politics and particularly the fate of Democrats in what are supposed to be the bluest of blue states.

Property taxes are high around here in large part, of course, because property values are high. But there are several reasons why property taxes are higher here than in other costly parts of the country. Unlike California and Massachusetts, there are few, if any, longstanding brakes in place that kept property taxes down (and, in California, led to disastrous revenue shortages). Public employees unions are powerful and politically feared. And we've come to expect good services -- top-rated schools, nearby police in little boutique towns -- and have been willing to pay for them.

The Nassau County executive, Thomas R. Suozzi, whose ''Fix Albany'' mantra got him nowhere when he ran for governor against Eliot Spitzer in 2006 but looks pretty smart in retrospect, says that property taxes are inseparable from dysfunction in state government. He cites several reasons why property taxes are so high: unreasonable state mandates piled on local governments; income tax dollars inequitably distributed back to local governments; far too many local governments -- more than 10,500 in New York -- that need to be consolidated or eliminated; fraud and waste; and economic stagnation producing no expansion in the property tax base. You could throw in crippling Medicaid costs and unsustainable pension costs.

''It's the No. 1 issue,'' he said. ''People have reached their breaking point. But we still have a long way to go in connecting the dots between dysfunction in state government and high property taxes.''

Still, breaking point or not, who knows where this goes? A Proposition 13-style temper tantrum? Painful cuts -- meaning teachers and police? Throw out the bums -- most likely Democrats, who could be fat targets in an antitax backlash? Lots of grumbling but living with an increasingly unaffordable status quo?

Gerald Prante, an economist with the Tax Foundation in Washington, said at least people feel they get something tangible from their local taxes and can tolerate them if they believe they're getting what they paid for. ''If I told you I spent $40,000 on a car, it doesn't tell you much unless you know what kind of car,'' he said. ''If it's a Lamborghini, it was probably a good deal. If it was a Saturn, it's not such a good deal.'' Thus, for all the angst, the fact that most local school budgets still routinely pass indicates we might be more likely to grumble than to cut close to home.

The problem is that many suburbanites who bought the luxury car a few years back now can barely afford the Saturn. The New Jersey race will provide some signals. Whether Republicans regain control of the Nassau County Legislature might provide some more. But the status quo can't last, and if there's a huge backlash, Democrats have the most to fear politically.

''The longer we wait, the harder the reckoning is going to be,'' Dr. Nathan said.

CHART: Counties paying the most in median real estate taxes in 2008 (Source: U.S. Census)

E-mail: peappl@nytimes.com

New York Times Digital (Full Text)

Document NYTF000020091005e5a500028


FILM REVIEW 'INVENTING LA'
The Arts/Cultural Desk; SECTC
The Los Angeles Times And the City It Grew
By MIKE HALE
605 words
5 October 2009
The New York Times
NYTF
Late Edition - Final
7
English
Copyright 2009 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

Journalists are very likely to have a different reaction than other viewers to the PBS documentary ''Inventing LA: The Chandlers and Their Times'' on Monday night. This isn't because of what it demonstrates about the current troubles of The Los Angeles Times or the newspaper industry in general, because it has practically nothing to say on those subjects.

The divergence will come earlier, during the film's account of The Times's first half-century, beginning in the 1890s. Normal viewers will see an interesting chapter in California history, a sordid tale of real estate and politics that will be slightly familiar to anyone who has watched ''Chinatown.''

Those who have devoted their lives to the business of daily print in more recent times, however, will be shaking their heads. Was it really possible that power of such magnitude -- diverting water supplies, building suburbs, playing a central role in the fastest growth any American city has ever seen -- could be exercised from the offices of a newspaper publisher?

Of course, we're meant to see the story of Harrison Gray Otis and his son-in-law Harry Chandler, the men who created The Los Angeles Times and cemented its power, as a cautionary tale. In their hands the newspaper was nothing more than a tool for union busting, race baiting, promoting their business ventures and getting their cronies elected to public office.

Which makes them fascinating subjects, and makes the first section of ''Inventing LA'' the part worth watching. Once we're past World War II and the narrative focuses on how later Chandlers like Norman and Otis turned the newspaper, whose quality had been an afterthought, into a world-class operation, a lot of the life goes out of the film.

The filmmaker, Peter Jones, has the problem endemic to histories of family dynasties: the families tend to get less interesting with each succeeding generation. There's on-screen proof of that here, in the numerous Chandlers Mr. Jones persuaded to sit for interviews about their more charismatic fathers, grandfathers and ex-husbands.

Dissension among the relatives -- the people Otis Chandler infamously characterized as ''coupon clippers'' living off the family fortune -- would eventually contribute to the decision to sell the Chandler newspaper holdings to the Tribune Company in 2000, and that's where ''Inventing LA'' ends.

Its focus on the family means that the years of cost cutting and sagging morale at The Times under Tribune ownership are left out, along with earlier incidents, like the Staples Center scandal involving editorial oversight, that didn't directly involve the Chandlers.

The story that interests Mr. Jones -- of naked capitalism and myth-making in the desert -- has been told before, in David Halberstam's 1979 book, ''The Powers That Be,'' and in books and essays by writers like Kevin Starr and Mike Davis, who appear in the film. But for most people the defining account remains ''Chinatown,'' Robert Towne and Roman Polanski's fictionalized version of Harry Chandler's water-and-land grab in the San Fernando Valley. If you've ever wondered what the real story was, the first hour of ''Inventing LA'' will fill you in.

INVENTING LA: THE CHANDLERS AND THEIR TIMES

On most PBS stations on Monday night (check local listings).

Written and directed by Peter Jones; co-directed, photographed and edited by Mark Catalena; Mr. Jones and Mr. Catalena, producers; Brian Tessier, supervising producer; Dennis McDougal, consulting producer; Earl Rose, composer; Liev Schreiber, narrator. Produced by Peter Jones Productions.

New York Times Digital (Full Text)

Document NYTF000020091005e5a500014


National Desk; SECTA
A Battle Over Low-Income Housing Reveals Post-Hurricane Tensions
By CAMPBELL ROBERTSON
1416 words
4 October 2009
The New York Times
NYTF
Late Edition - Final
16
English
Copyright 2009 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

CHALMETTE, La. -- The parish of St. Bernard, a quiet, insular suburb just east of New Orleans, has in the end agreed to allow housing for low-income families.

But even though it is only a few hundred apartment units, it had to be ordered by a federal judge. The parish has fought desperately to prevent such housing and an influx of renters, at one point even approving a law that prohibited homeowners from renting to anyone other than a blood relative, before it was challenged and repealed.

The battle over low-income housing has been one of the most bitter that anyone in the middle-class, mostly white parish can remember, one that has stoked issues the region has been grappling with since Hurricane Katrina: anger at the federal government and long-simmering class and racial tensions.

It also reflects widespread anxiety about just how drastically the area changed after the floodwaters receded.

''I think people have adopted this issue as one that goes far beyond the reality of its impact,'' said Craig Taffaro Jr., the parish president. ''It tapped into the soul of our recovery.''

Providing housing for low-income families has been one of the most vexing problems for the New Orleans area in the four years since the hurricane. Tens of thousands of homes, many of them dilapidated, are still vacant. But, in part because the houses that were destroyed were disproportionately for low-income renters, market rents in the city are 35 percent higher than they were before the storm, out of the reach of much of the city's work force.

The demolition of the four big public housing complexes in New Orleans in 2007 and the approaching end to storm-related federal assistance programs have made these problems more critical, and their solutions more contentious.

That is particularly true in the case of St. Bernard, perhaps the jurisdiction hit the hardest by Hurricane Katrina. Nearly every one of the 26,000 houses there was severely damaged or destroyed. Ninety-three percent of them were owned by whites.

Four years later, over half of the parish residences are still vacant or unoccupied, according to the Greater New Orleans Community Data Center. The population, at around 37,000, is just more than half of what it was. Many former residents sold their homes to investors. Thousands of people displaced from elsewhere have moved in.

The parish has not welcomed these changes.

In September 2006, the Parish Council passed a law that prohibited owners of single-family residences from renting to anyone except blood relatives, except by special approval by the Council.

Parish officials say it was intended to guarantee that neighborhoods would consist largely of owner-occupied homes, with some accommodation for current residents.

But advocates for low-income housing say it was a blatantly racist policy, given the overwhelmingly white ownership in the parish. St. Bernard officials dropped the ordinance after a lawsuit by the Greater New Orleans Fair Housing Action Center.

''It's loaded in a way no one can miss,'' said John Relman, a civil rights lawyer who represented the center in the suit, adding that he had never come across such a rule before.

Then, last year, a Dallas-based firm called Realty Advisors proposed building four new apartment complexes, at $60 million, in the parish. Thirty percent of the 288 apartments would be rented at market rates. The rest would be set aside for low-income renters.

Reaction among parish residents was swift. Amid grim forecasts of crime, ghettoes and blight, parish officials declared a moratorium on building any apartment complexes with five or more units.

David Jarrell, an attorney for Sidney D. Torres III, one of the local backers of the apartments, said the anger came largely from an aversion to renters, even though a number of council members are landlords themselves.

And race, Mr. Jarrell said, was certainly a factor.

''It is what it is,'' he said. ''Anybody that says otherwise is being disingenuous.''

Parish officials denied that they were trying to keep out blacks, saying the parish simply needs more houses, not apartments. They said they would not object if the project involved filling up all the vacant lots already in the parish instead of building new high-density housing.

''It's a very good idea if we needed it,'' said Earl Dauterive, the chairman of the St. Bernard planning commission. ''We just don't need it.''

Despite the fury the development has stirred up, no one -- neither the opponents nor the supporters -- knows what the likely racial makeup of the tenants would be, and it is possible that few black families would apply to live in the parish.

Race and class make for a complicated mix in this region. Proposed low- or mixed-income developments have met with staunch opposition all over the New Orleans area, in both predominately white suburbs and in primarily black neighborhoods in the city limits.

A development of 35 single-family, lease-to-own homes in the black middle-class neighborhood of New Orleans East was blocked by the New Orleans City Council in August. The arguments against it -- that it would damage property values and quality of life -- were similar to those heard in St. Bernard. The developer, a New Orleans native living in Atlanta, is considering a discrimination lawsuit, even though almost everyone on both sides of the issue is black.

James Perry, executive director of the housing center and a candidate for mayor of New Orleans, said class animosity might be at the root of much of this anger, though discrimination against the poor is not a violation of the Fair Housing Act. It is illegal to discriminate against minorities, however, and given that a disproportionate number of those who need affordable housing in the area are black, he said, these arguments almost inevitably involve race.

Nowhere has the outcry against low-income housing been as intense as it has been in St. Bernard, particularly since Provident Realty took the parish to court this year. What followed was a season of acrimony, with parish officials doing everything possible to prevent the development from breaking ground. Construction has to begin by this fall if the developer is to qualify for the special disaster-relief tax credits that would make the development profitable.

At every turn, a federal judge in New Orleans has ruled that the parish's actions were simply camouflaged racism and last month ordered that the parish move forward on the development or face steep daily fines. The parish is appealing her rulings.

Parish officials, already angered by what they see as a failure of the federal government to help them after Hurricane Katrina, were livid that a federal judge was now a force in their rebuilding. Mr. Taffaro, in a weekly column on the parish Web site, described the lawsuit ''as a means to perpetuate the breakdown of true freedom of American society.''

At one hearing, a witness for Provident testified that a quarter of St. Bernard residents could not afford market rents. But even many of the parish's poorest residents oppose the apartments.

''We don't need it,'' said Frances Graf, 48, a resident who bought a FEMA trailer from the government for $5 and who gathers daily with other residents at the food bank run by the Community Center of St. Bernard. ''It's going to cause more problems. There ain't no jobs down here.''

Those around her at the food bank agreed and said there was no shortage of ''for rent'' signs in the parish.

Then there was that other objection.

''You know what it's going to bring,'' said Kathy Gonzales, 55, who lives in a house owned by a relative of her husband and whose rent is subsidized by a Section 8 voucher. ''I'm not going to say it, but you know.''

PHOTOS: Abandoned apartment buildings in Chalmette, La., that were flooded by Hurricane Katrina. The parish population, about 37,000, is roughly half of what it was.; CRAIG TAFFARO: JR. President of St. Bernard Parish; FRANCES GRAF: Resident who bought a FEMA trailer (pg. A16); Kathy Gonzales, a resident of St. Bernard Parish whose rent is subsidized, opposes a plan for a low-income housing complex.(PHOTOGRAPHS BY LEE CELANO FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)(pg. A20)

MAP: St. Bernard was badly damaged by Hurricane Katrina. (pg. A20)

New York Times Digital (Full Text)

Document NYTF000020091004e5a40008z


THE HUNT
Real Estate Desk; SECTRE
The Tram Trade-Off
By JOYCE COHEN
1281 words
4 October 2009
The New York Times
NYTF
Late Edition - Final
4
English
Copyright 2009 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

ONCE their children had left the nest, Ruth and Mark Thomas were eager to follow. They had little interest in keeping their Long Island house.

''Everything was a problem,'' Mrs. Thomas said. Great effort and expense rarely yielded anything enjoyable or rewarding. ''I don't get to buy a new sofa. I get to have a new water heater. For our 12th anniversary we got a new septic system or something. It's like: Oh, look! I can flush the toilet and not flood the den.''

And Mr. Thomas had a commute of an hour and 45 minutes each way. ''It made for insanely long days,'' his wife said. ''We could never go out during the week.'' In summer, she would barbecue on the beach with friends, and ''by the time he got there, we were packing up.''

The Thomases, who are in their early 50s, met as students at Syracuse University and lived in Manhattan for a decade before moving to the suburbs. In 1987, they bought a cute Victorian house in Oyster Bay. Then, with two small children, they moved to Locust Valley. ''I traded quaint for a 1955 split level,'' Mrs. Thomas said. ''I went for bathrooms and space.'' Their new place, with four bedrooms and four bathrooms, had almost 2,500 square feet.

But now their son, Jeff, 21, is a senior at George Washington University, while their daughter, Leah, 23, lives in Brooklyn with her fiance.

Mr. Thomas's journey to his office at 59th Street and Lexington Avenue, where he works in advertising sales for Bloomberg Markets magazine, had five legs.

The easiest, quickest way entailed a drive to the Long Island Rail Road station, a train to Jamaica, a switch to Woodside, a Flushing-line jaunt to Queensboro Plaza and, finally, one stop on the N, R or W train across the East River. ''I would spread out on the train and read the paper,'' he said. ''It wasn't great.''

A year ago, the couple put their house on the market. One day per weekend, they would clean all morning and leave for the afternoon. ''We saw every lousy movie made,'' said Mrs. Thomas, who has worked as an interior decorator and a caterer. She always baked her specialty, sweet-smelling cinnamon bread, for visitors. When there were no lookers, which was often, their two real estate agents gladly helped themselves.

''Trying to sell in this market was horrible,'' Mrs. Thomas said. They didn't look for a Manhattan rental until last spring, when they discerned glimmers of interest in their house. They hoped to rent a two-bedroom two-bathroom apartment for $4,000 to $5,000 a month, eager to give up the responsibilities that came with owning, and to shorten the wearying commute.

Beyond that, the priority was finding a quiet place. ''If it's not quiet, Mark doesn't care how nice it is,'' Mrs. Thomas said. Once, in Manhattan, three German shepherds lived above them. ''It sounded like herds of elephants.''

Their hunt focused largely on the Upper East Side. On York Avenue, they checked out the Andover near 89th Street and the Barclay near 92nd Street, both owned by Glenwood Management, which has 24 luxury rental buildings around the city. Rents for two-bedrooms were $4,595 to $4,995 a month.

''We were pretty pleased with what we found,'' Mrs. Thomas said. The apartments ''were basically exactly the same. We have a friend who is in one of them for about 25 years. We've seen how nice they kept it up.''

She liked Claridge House, on East 87th Street, even more. A two-bedroom there seemed especially big, with plenty of closet space. She was ready to move right in. (Two-bedrooms in the building currently start at $4,650, with a free month on a 13-month lease.)

But after they saw it, they still had time to kill. On John Gambling's radio show, Mrs. Thomas heard an advertisement for Riverwalk Crossing, a rental building, and Riverwalk Court, the condominium next door, on Roosevelt Island. It was memorable, because ''an ad for an apartment building is not something I normally hear,'' she said. The ad noted the buildings' proximity to Manhattan, ''sweeping panoramic views'' and ''bountiful greenery.'' So she suggested they take a look.

The Thomases had never been to Roosevelt Island. ''I think years ago we might have taken the tram and not even stepped onto the island -- just for the fun of it,'' Mrs. Thomas said.

Mr. Thomas was hesitant. Why bother? But his wife insisted. At the very least, the tram was still fun.

When they saw an apartment at the 18-story Riverwalk Crossing, he instantly changed his mind. ''This one has a wow factor, with more space, wonderful views and 30 percent less money,'' he said.

By now, the Locust Valley house was on the verge of selling. It finally did, in midsummer, for $650,000 to a couple from Queens with two daughters. (Four years ago, faced with a possible job transfer, the Thomases had accepted an offer for $910,000. The transfer never happened.)

Their 1,250-square-foot apartment, with nobody above them, has a knockout view of Manhattan. ''I feel we have the best apartment in the place,'' Mr. Thomas said.

Their rent is $4,080 a month, with another $250 a year for the gym and $125 a year for bike storage per bike. Their one parking spot is $180 a month.

The two feel almost apologetic about two things. One is moving to Roosevelt Island. People mention it with an edge of disdain -- at least until they visit and see the view, which Mr. Thomas compares to a view from a ship deck. The other is renting. To judge from people's reactions, ''it's almost like we did something dirty,'' Mrs. Thomas said.

Roosevelt Island isn't much for restaurants or shopping. ''In Manhattan proper,'' Mr. Thomas said, ''you can just run downstairs and find something to eat really quick. So it is more of a trip for dining and grabbing a snack, but that is part of the trade-off.''

Mrs. Thomas, who is now a private chef, has no trouble in her smaller kitchen. She bakes cinnamon bread and feeds it to the building's staff.

But, living in the city, she has to ''learn how to do everything all over again,'' she said. ''I am used to jumping in the car and driving to the Dairy Barn in my pajamas.'' (Dairy Barn is a chain of drive-through stores on Long Island.) City living requires ''a whole different mind-set.''

Her welcome to the city was the theft of her credit card from her bag. (The thief bought MetroCards.) Still, she likes the city better than before.

Fellow tram riders are warm and polite. It's like ''the first day of a new school, and everybody is new in the school and friendly with each other,'' she said.

As for Mr. Thomas's commute, he has a tram ride and a one-block walk.

''He is unbearably happy,'' his wife said. ''If you see somebody skipping to work, it's my husband.''

E-mail: thehunt@nytimes.com

PHOTOS: The Barclay on York Avenue near 92nd Street was a well-kept rental building.; A large two-bedroom at Claridge House, on 87th Street, had plenty of closet space.; Mark and Ruth Thomas enjoy the stunning views of Manhattan.; Riverwalk Crossing on Roosevelt Island delivered a ''wow factor.''(PHOTOGRAPHS BY SUZANNE DECHILLO/THE NEW YORK TIMES)

New York Times Digital (Full Text)

Document NYTF000020091004e5a40008y


Metropolitan Desk; SECTMB
Man of 4,000 Rooms
By CHARLES V. BAGLI
2574 words
4 October 2009
The New York Times
NYTF
Late Edition - Final
1
English
Copyright 2009 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

Sam Chang, the hotel king of New York, surveyed a portion of his domain from West 39th Street, a gritty block south of the Port Authority, from where he can see not one, not two, but a half-dozen of his hotel sites on a single block. ''They ought to name this block for me,'' he said.

Mr. Chang, 49, a compact man with a brush cut, then marched through the lobby of his Hampton Inn, one of three hotels he shoehorned into a single 32-story building. On the 20th floor, he opened a door to a secret of his success: Two beds, a desk and bureaus somehow sat comfortably in a room the size of a Park Avenue closet: 250 square feet, about $200 a night.

''It's small compared to a regular hotel,'' Mr. Chang conceded. ''But as long as you customize the furniture, you don't feel it.''

In a city known for the glamour of its landmark hotels -- like the gilded Waldorf-Astoria or the storied Plaza -- and the anonymity of its flophouses, Mr. Chang has built an empire of beds for a heretofore ignored class: the budget traveler. And no one has ever built more hotels in the city than Mr. Chang, who has created 37 and has 22 more in the works.

Over the past decade, his limited-service Comfort Inns, Holiday Inn Expresses and Hilton Gardens have helped change the commercial cityscape along with Red Lobster and Applebee's. ''I've got a lot of records in New York,'' he said, then recited them.

Narrowest hotel: Hotel Reserve, 51 Nassau Street, 18 feet across.

First ''three pack'' (three hotels in one building): Hampton Inn, Candlewood Suites and Holiday Inn Express, on 39th Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, which opened this summer.

First Asian-American to build a high-rise hotel in Manhattan: the 24-story Hilton Garden Inn, at 119 West 28th Street, in 2006.

''People just don't recognize it,'' he said.

Investors, real estate brokers and hotel chains love Mr. Chang. Community groups, some elected officials and the hotel and construction unions, not so much. Critics contend he has built his empire barely within city codes and are vowing to stop his freewheeling, nonunion operations in manufacturing districts like the garment center of Manhattan.

''Sam is a guy where, if you sign a deal with him, it better be signed in blood,'' said Steve McInnis, political director of the New York City District Council of Carpenters. ''He's definitely on our watch list.''

A year ago, Mr. Chang, a high school dropout turned mogul, predicted he would retire in 2010. But in a concession to hard times, he said he had pushed his retirement date to 2013 and dumped his bodyguard, though not his Rolex or his 2.5-carat diamond ring.

In 2006, Mr. Chang told Fortune magazine that he had $200 million in cash. Today, he dodges the question of his wealth. After creating 4,344 rooms in the city at a torrid pace since 1998, Mr. Chang has slowed with the economy. Room rates and property values are down sharply, making it difficult to sell the hotels at all, never mind getting buyers to pay twice what he paid to build them, as he did during the boom.

And some of the 4,000 rooms Mr. Chang has under development, including projects in the Bronx and on the Bowery, are stalled; the Buildings Department has issued a stop-work order on an 11-story hotel near Union Square for failure to maintain safety equipment and safeguard people and property on the site; and he has a second ''three-pack'' under construction on Staten Island, where the market has nosedived.

Mr. Chang, who has taken two trips to bankruptcy court in the past, said he would not make it a trifecta. ''I'm more conservative now on debt,'' he said. ''We have operating hotels producing a cash flow. I'm just going to slow down and continue to do what I'm good at.''

For a long time -- let's call it the Pre-Chang Period -- the hotel market in New York operated on some widely embraced tenets. Given the high cost of land, developers focused on building luxury hotels like the Four Seasons or the Mandarin Oriental. Their target guest: the business executive on an expense account. Travelers unwilling to pay hundreds of dollars a night were left to choose from worn tourist hotels like the Carter and the Milford Plaza, or lodgings in New Jersey.

Mr. Chang's innovation was to bring the limited-service brands that line the highways of Middle America, like Holiday Inn Express or Hilton Garden Inn, to its commercial capital. These hotels did not have restaurants or room service -- usually just a breakfast bar with make-your-own waffles -- but they had clean rooms and international reservations systems, and could command respectable rates from $100 to $220 a night. The surprising little secret: they had a higher profit margin than their upscale brethren.

The chains were so eager to get into New York City that Mr. Chang was able to persuade them to set aside their cookie-cutter standards, designing custom furniture to fill 200-square-foot rooms in Manhattan instead of their typical 350 square feet.

''It's a bit spartan,'' said Carole Lincoln, a visitor from England who spent some time last month in a $147-a-night room at Mr. Chang's Holiday Inn Express on 39th Street. ''But it's what I expected for the price. It's clean and it's centrally located.''

To hedge the risk of buying more than $150 million in properties, Mr. Chang brought in partners, like Hersha Hospitality Trust, Magna Hospitality Group and Gemini Real Estate Advisors, who sometimes financed and frequently bought the hotels before or shortly after completion. He managed to control development costs in part by becoming partners in a construction company. And he searched for inexpensive parcels on narrow midblock sites that were zoned for manufacturing, not residential or commercial towers, but had a loophole allowing hotels.

''It seems like a simple formula,'' said Thomas McConnell, senior managing director of Cushman & Wakefield, a real estate brokerage that has worked with Mr. Chang on several deals, ''but he was the only one who did it, and did it without much of an organization.''

Mr. Chang, it turns out, is an organization all by himself, a hard-bargaining dealmaker who acts swiftly and carries most of the details in his head, sharing little information about his partners with anyone. With little effort, he can rattle off the number of hotels, the number of rooms in each and how much he paid for a particular parcel of land.

''Three words describe Sam Chang,'' Mr. Chang likes to say. ''Working. Working. Working.''

He defied the accepted wisdom by building 17 hotels on the once-industrial West Side of Manhattan between 24th and 44th Streets, often making a decision on the spot about whether to snatch up an available property. He named his company the McSam Hotel Group.

''He'd buy without due diligence,'' said Alan P. Miller, senior director of Eastern Consolidated, a real estate brokerage firm, who has worked with Mr. Chang. ''He pays all cash. Gambler or not, he's an expert hotel builder.''

With Mr. Chang, everything is for sale. For years, he has bought and sold a succession of increasingly larger houses on Long Island.

Since 2006, home has been a six-bedroom, $3 million estate with a private lake on 18 acres in secluded Centre Island, where Billy Joel is a neighbor. That house is now on the market.

In the garage is Mr. Chang's 2006 birthday present to himself: a Maybach, a limited-edition, $500,000 German sedan. He likes to describe how the rear seats can slide into a horizontal position, like the first-class seats on a jet. There is also a Rolls-Royce and a Mercedes.

Mr. Chang throws an annualNew Year's Eve party in Flushing for 200 real estate, construction and financing executives. He is, by his estimation, a ''good drinker'' who prefers Johnny Walker Blue, a rare Scotch that sells for $220 a bottle.

The expensive jewelry, the fancy liquor and the big houses and cars are a form of revenge, said his friend Michael Kang, an architect who designed some of Mr. Chang's hotels in Queens. When Mr. Chang moved to New York in 1996, he was broke and many people in the Chinese community looked down on him, Mr. Kang said. ''They said he was a nobody.''

Born in Taiwan, Shan Leong Chang moved to Japan with his family when he was a child. He left school at 17 because, he said, he did not want to waste time. ''I tell everybody I went to homemade college,'' he said.

He came to the United States in 1977 to help his parents run the 11-room Richards Motel in downtown Los Angeles. By the early 1980s, he had moved to Baltimore, where he operated a succession of Chinese restaurants before buying his first hotel, in Hagerstown, Md., with financing from Taiwanese investors and his cousins. Straining under debt during the recession in 1990, Mr. Chang tumbled into bankruptcy court, where he lost five hotels.

He quickly bounced back, assembling a dozen hotels between Boston and Washington. After a dispute with his cousins, Mr. Chang went to Natchez, Miss., in an ill-fated bid to open a riverboat casino. When he filed for bankruptcy a second time, in 1996, he had $300 in his pocket and $27.7 million in debts, according to court records.

''He fell in love with every deal that came across his desk,'' said Alan M. Grochal, a Baltimore lawyer who worked for Mr. Chang at the time. ''A lot of dead-dog losers. He had an incredible amount of debt arising out of many, many deals.''

Within months, Mr. Chang was back in business, now in New York, where he struggled to build a Howard Johnson's in Flushing and what became a Comfort Inn at Kennedy Airport. He was rapidly running out of money when he met a wealthy Chinatown garment factory owner, John Lam, who became his financial partner for seven years.

Mr. Lam ultimately split off and created his own company, and is now a rival. Mr. Chang now owns 31 hotels around the country, including 12 of the 37 he has built in New York. Another two are in Anchorage, Alaska, a stopover on his frequent trips to China. ''I figured if I have to stop in Alaska,'' he said, ''I should own some hotels there.''

Mr. Chang's hotels have been popular with budget travelers, but not with New York City community boards or the construction and hotel workers' unions. Since December 2006, his construction company, Tritel, has accumulated 207 serious building violations, 47 of which are still unresolved. Community Board 7 in the Bronx often found him unresponsive when work on a hotel near Fordham University weakened the foundation of an adjoining home, flooding the basement.

''Their whole approach to the community was very dismissive,'' said Gregory Faulkner, chairman of the community board.

Some construction unions clashed with Mr. Chang in 2006, while he was building three hotels on the West Side with nonunion contractors. After a pitched battle on the street, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo opened an investigation into claims that one of Mr. Chang's subcontractors was paying immigrant workers substandard wages and using a two-tiered system that offered higher pay for young Irish workers than for Brazilians from Newark.

Mr. Chang later worked out an agreement with the carpenters' union to use union contractors on his larger projects, but that appears to be unraveling.

The Hotel Trades Council, which represents workers at most large hotels in Manhattan, sees Mr. Chang as a direct threat. The union recently persuaded the Bloomberg administration to create a special permit requiring City Council approval to develop hotels in manufacturing districts.

''What this city can't afford is an oversupply of limited-service hotels in manufacturing zones, which will inevitably squeeze out the remaining industrial jobs in the city,'' said Neal Kwatra, political director of the trades council.

Asked about the safety, community and union complaints, Mr. Chang played down the criticism, and said it was difficult to avoid citations while building in New York, particularly given the current crackdown on safety. He said his companies worked quickly to fix problems, whether with the Buildings Department or community boards.

''There have been issues with various constituencies,'' acknowledged Mr. Chang's main architect, Gene Kaufman. ''All have been worked out satisfactorily for both sides.''

In any event, hotel operators are caught between slumping business travel and a glut of more than 10,000 new hotel rooms that have opened in New York City over the past few years.

Room rates and revenues at both budget and luxury hotels have dropped 30 percent, according to the hotel consulting firm Lodging Advisors, which estimates that that translates into a 60 percent cut in profits. The hotel occupancy rate in Manhattan dropped to 76 percent this year from 84 percent a year ago, according to PKF Consulting, though July occupancy was 84 percent, the same level as in July 2008.

''I think it's going to be a struggle for Sam to achieve the rates and occupancy that he had projected when he conceived of these projects,'' said Jeff Davis, executive vice president of Jones Lang LaSalle Hotels, a real estate management and investment firm.

In a sign of stress, Mr. Chang has not been paying the interest-only loans for four projects financed by Hersha Hospitality Trust. Hersha acknowledged in a conference call with hotel analysts in August that it decided to add the unpaid payments to the principal on the loan.

William T. Obeid, chief executive of Gemini Real Estate Advisors, which has bought three hotels from Mr. Chang, also was upbeat about Mr. Chang's future.

''He's an incredible survivor, an incredible fighter,'' Mr. Obeid said. ''He is not going to let these projects just fall by the wayside. There's value, maybe not as much as there was 18 months ago, but he'll figure out the situation.''

PHOTOS: MOTELS MANHATTAN STYLE: Sam Chang on West 39th Street, where he has a ''three-pack'' of connected budget-conscious hotels. Below, Mr. Chang looks out at what he calls a copycat competitor from the interior of his Hampton Inn on West 39th.(MB1); SNUG FIT: Sam Chang at the Hampton Inn, where two beds, a desk and bureaus fit into 250 square feet, for about $200 a night.(PHOTOGRAPHS BY NICOLE BENGIVENO/THE NEW YORK TIMES)(MB6)

MAP: Building a Hotel Fortune: Sam Chang is responsible for building 37 hotels in New York City, more than any other person. He is currently working on 22 new hotel projects around the five boroughs. Mr. Chang has brought to the city the affordable hotel brands found in the rest of the country, like Holiday Inn Express and Comfort Inn. These chains fill a void between the luxury hotels and the worn lodgings that have traditionally been the options for tourists needing a bed in the big city.(MB6)

BIG DEAL
Real Estate Desk; SECTRE
Big Is Beautiful
By JOSH BARBANEL
688 words
4 October 2009
The New York Times
NYTF
Late Edition - Final
2
English
Copyright 2009 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

IN a year of doom and gloom, the granite postmodern towers overlooking Central Park at 15 Central Park West at West 62nd Street have been a beacon of hope for the battered luxury real estate market in Manhattan.

So far this year, as sales stalled across the city, owners of eight of the 201 apartments (there are also 30 staff suites) in the building have sold their units at prices 38 percent above the original closing prices of August 2007, when the building opened, city property records show. That works out to a cumulative gain of $21.9 million, judging by property records filed through the middle of last week.

Now, brokers say that with the larger Manhattan market no longer in free fall, interest is quickening in the building's largest and most expensive apartments with the best views. This includes the recent $37 million sale of a 5,276-square-foot four-bedroom penthouse on the 40th floor, with views of Central Park, the Hudson River and the George Washington Bridge.

That price makes the apartment one of the five or six most expensive condos ever traded in Manhattan -- and the third highest sale yet at 15 Central Park West, even taking into account far larger units. The price works out to more than $7,000 a square foot.

Sanford I. Weill, the former chairman and chief executive of Citigroup, paid $42.4 million, or $6,287 a square foot, for a full-floor penthouse atop the tower facing Central Park, widely regarded as the most luxurious apartment in the building. Mr. Weill signed a contract in May 2006 and closed at the end of August 2007.

That doesn't mean that 15 Central Park West hasn't been the scene of some disappointments during the downturn. Gotham Makker, an investor and former portfolio manager at the Citadel Investment Group, sold a 28th-floor apartment at an $800,000 loss in August, according to property records. He bought it in spring 2008, at the peak of the Manhattan market, for $13.3 million, nearly double the original sale price of the year before.

And the visions of $100 million apartments in the building have been dashed, at least for the time being, by the recession. Richard Wallgren, a broker at Brown Harris Stevens, who represented the developers in the original sales, was needled by other brokers when an $80 million listing he posted last year at 15 Central Park West was cut to ''only'' $47 million in February, possibly the largest price cut ever.

It turns out Mr. Wallgren was overreaching even with that price. But the apartment has sold for $37 million, according to brokers briefed on the transaction, and the chuckles have died down. The seller was identified as Amit Ben-Haim, a London investor who in 1999 made a fortune through the $400 million sale to Johnson & Johnson of an Israeli medical device company founded by his brother.

The apartment has five and a half bathrooms, and the sale price includes a separate 1,100-square-foot ground-floor apartment for employees or a home office. Brokers say that a smaller high-floor apartment has also gone into contract recently for a price well over $20 million.

''The building is uniquely positioned, better than any other building in Manhattan, to go up in price,'' said Ryan Sherman, a broker and a principal at Metropolitan Residential Partners, who recently sold two apartments there. ''Anything above the lower floors that was always desirable is continuing to rise in value.''

Last month, Mr. Sherman represented Bruce Kaye, a real estate executive with interests in Atlantic City, in the sale of his 2,367-square-foot two-bedroom apartment on the 32nd floor for $11.7 million, or nearly $5,000 a square foot. Mr. Kaye and his wife, Deborah, bought the apartment in April 2008 for $7.8 million, and realized a gain of 50 percent in 17 months. The purchaser was an international shipping executive, brokers said.

PHOTO: 15 Central Park West
